titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went out to Quincy this morning in a Chair with Whitcomb— He returned to Boston to dinner, leaving me there— Heard Mr: Whitney the father in the afternoon— He had dined at my father’s— I went up to my own house, and found that almost all the young trees, which had come up from the stones and seeds I had sown the last Summer had perished— Generally devoured by Insects— Many of those I planted last Spring however, are now coming up; and the young walnuts, which appeared to have died in the Winter, are all sending out new shoots— Many of my young transplanted peach-trees have also been destroyed by the Ants.— Sent the deed to Mrs: Adams.

2. Came into Boston this Morning in the Stage— The Circuit Court of the United States commenced its Session— Judge Cushing was ill and could not attend— The Court was therefore opened by the District Judge Davis. This was the Artillery Election— I heard part of the Sermon, preached by Mr: Kendall of Plymouth— Dined by invitation with the Company at Faneuil Hall— The dinner was very dull— Afternoon at my Chamber— Evening, walking with J. Gardner in the Mall.

3. Attended the Circuit Court, the whole day, but there was little business done. Judge Cushing still being absent. My attendance upon the Court however takes me away altogether from business, which I ought more particularly to attend to— J. Hall spent the whole afternoon with me at my chamber, (the Court adjourned to the morning, before dinner) In the Evening I called on J. Phillips, who kept me with him to supper— My brother and Mr: Cranch were in town— The former dined with us.

4. Mr: Phillips called upon me this morning, and we finished the business upon which we had yesterday agreed— I attended again all day at the Circuit Court. Heard a cause argued to the Court, respecting a conveyance of Mr: Smith to his creditors— My brother and his wife came in from Quincy, and brought my youngest child with them— I went to see him at Mr: Foster’s— Walk’d in the Evening with Mr: J. Gardner; and he came home and supp’d with me.

bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 5. Attended Court again— The Cause concerning Mr: Smith’s conveyance was finished— But in the afternoon Judge Cushing did not attend, and the Court immediately adjourn’d— President Webber called upon me this afternoon, and informed me of the assignment of next Thursday afternoon, for my instalment as Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at Cambridge.— My business connected with that subject continues much interrupted.

6. Mr: Parsons was yesterday sworn as Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court of the State; and therefore did not appear this day, as Counsellor in the Circuit Court— They sat all this day, but did very little business— My brother was in town, and dined with us. I employed all the leisure of the day in reading, & found no time to write.

7. My Mother and brother came into Boston this Morning— I attended the Circuit Court, and obtained judgment against H. Jackson— Dined with Mr: Allen the Sheriff.— Governor Strong, Mr: A. Welles, Mr: W. Phillips and Mr: S. Codman with my brother constituted the company— In the Evening I went out to Quincy with my mother— I received no letter this day from my wife, and am very anxious lest the disappointment should have been occasioned by her being ill.

8. Heard Mr: Whitney. The day was excessively warm, but in the afternoon there was a heavy thunder shower, which continued about an hour: in the Evening the weather cleared off again— I spent it principally at Mr: Cranch’s— Wrote to Mrs: Adams.

9. Returned to Boston this morning with my brother— Attended the Circuit Court, which sat only in the forenoon. In the afternoon I was not well, and spent it as well as the Evening at home reading the first Volume of Marmontel’s Memoirs of his own Life.

10. Attended the Circuit Court which sat only the forenoon— Judge Cushing being still unwell did not come out. Afternoon reading Marmontel’s Memoirs— Evening walk’d in the Mall with J. Gardner— I am again interrupted from the pursuit of my proper business— Received a letter from my wife, who has been very ill.— Answered.

11. Called at the Alms-House for my gown, but it was not finished, and Mr Norcross is so ill, that there was no prospect, he could finish it— I took away, and searched two or three hours without success for a Mrs: Smith to whom he had sent me— I was therefore compell’d to give up the pursuit and to borrow a gown for to-morrow— I dined by
invitation with the Society of lawyers, proprietors of the library.— I left them early in the afternoon— Evening at home— This day, very suddenly, after a long and violent struggle, both Houses of the Legislature declared Mr: Strong Governor of the Commonwealth—

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 12. Between 12 and 1. O’Clock I went to Cambridge— I was in a Chaise alone, but met Mr: Barrett of Quincy, and took him with me— My father and the family at Quincy came into town, and went also to Cambridge before dinner— I Dined with my father, Mr: Boylston and Professor Ware, at President Webber’s— In the afternoon, I was installed as Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory— The hour fixed for the purpose was half past three; but just at that time there arose a violent thunder gust and shower, which delayed the performances about two hours— From the philosophy chamber, where there was a meeting of the Corporation and Overseers, we went in procession to the meeting-house— About 5 in the afternoon— The President began by an introductory prayer— Next followed an Anthem— Then An Address by the President in Latin— Mr: Ware read the regulations of the Professorship— I read and subscribed the declaration, and delivered it to the Governor as Chairman of the Overseers—the President then declared me a Professor, and I delivered the discourse I had prepared for the Occasion; it was well received; but the company present was very small— The business was concluded by a hymn sung— The procession returned to the Philosophy Chamber; where I stopp’d only a few minutes. I took tea at Mr: Ware’s— Mr: & Mrs: Stoughton were there; as was Mr: Barrett—with him, I returned to Boston, and pass’d the Evening at Mr: Storer’s— My father and mother were there—& Mr: Peabody came in while I was there. Mr: Strong was this day sworn as Governor of the State— Mr: Heath, who was chosen Lieutenant Governor, declined accepting the Office.

13. The Circuit Court adjourned; Judge Cushing having been unable to attend the whole week.— Mr: Cranch’s business, and many other suits were necessarily continued in consequence of this circumstance— I dined with Mr: Jonathan Jackson the late Treasurer of this Commonwealth, for Tompson J. Skinner was this day chosen Treasurer for the year ensuing.— Mr: Hastings & Mr: Starkweather, two members of the Senate, and Mr: Parsons of Chesterfield, a member of the House of Representatives were there— And Mr: Wendell late a Counsellor; for an entire new set of Counsillors was also this day chosen— At 4. this afternoon I attended a meeting of the philosophical Society of which I was formerly a member— Dr: Kirkland read some observations upon the eclipse, which is to be expected next Monday— I afterwards spent most of the Evening with Chief-Justice Parsons; & afterwards took a solitary walk in the Mall— Read 2. Vol: Marmontel’s Memoirs— Our Legislature made this day, an entire new choice of Notaries Public; completely changing the holder of every Office in their appointment— Jonathan Loring Austin is the Secretary, in the place of Mr: Avery who died last Saturday.

14. Found a vessel, going to Alexandria, advertised to sail to-morrow morning, but I found upon enquiry she would not sail untill a day or two after— Bespoke a passage for the box I am to send to Mrs: Adams.— In the afternoon, I went in the stage to Quincy— Abby Shaw went with me.— I found Mr: Marston, and his family at my father’s, where there was also Mr: Beale and his family.— I had again this day no letter from my wife.

15. Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham in the Morning— After dinner a shower of Rain came up and detained me at home. It was clear however in the Evening, and I went to Mr: Quincy’s— My brother and his wife also came and spent an hour there— Wrote to Mrs: Adams— Read the pamphlet recently published in Boston on the Eclipse.

16. Returned to Boston this Morning in the Quincy Stage— I soon after went to Mr: Bussey’s; in whose garden, the gentlemen of the philosophical Society met to take the observation of the Solar Eclipse— It commenced at 3 minutes 21 seconds past 10 in the morning.— At XI.22.38 the total obscurity commenced. At XI.27.9. The first ray of the Sun,
blazed out from behind the moon. and at XII.48.1. the Eclipse ended. The total obscuration continued more than four minutes and a half— The sky during the whole time was unusually clear, and not a speck of cloud was visible on the horizon— At the commencement of the eclipse the thermometer in the shade stood at 68— It fell gradually, untill the end of the total obscurity, when it stood at 57.— There it remained stationary about a quarter of an hour—then began to rise, untill at the end of the eclipse it was at 67. and a few minutes after at 70— The fading of the Sun’s light, from its greatest splendour, untill its total extinction was peculiar, differing much from that of the usual declining day, on the approach of Evening— Six or eight Stars were visible, during a considerable part of the time. The planet Venus particularly appeared as large and as bright in the darkness, as it usually does in the Evening— The Colours of natural objects appeared to the eye with a tinge different from any thing I had ever seen. during the total concealment of the Sun, The Center of the Moon’s disk, appeared black as ebony; but the shade appeared gradually less black to the circumference, which was of a dusky brown— A feeble luminous circle, not equally light in every part surrounded the edge of the moon, and beyond that circle, a coruscation fainter and fainter shot forth in angular aspects extended to a distance equal to about the semidiameter of the moon; the western side of the hemisphere being that from which the moon advanced, was much darker than the Eastward on which part the sun’s rays were last shut in, and during the whole time the borders of the horizon were very luminous throughout their extent— The darkness was about equal to that of half an hour after Sun-set at this Season of the year— Or much like the darkness of midnight, which I have witness’d in June, at St: Petersburg.— About fifteen seconds before the first returning Sun-beam, a line of deep crimson, appeared on the moon’s edge, on the limb, where the Sun was about to issue— But the most striking appearance was the first returning beam; it was about two seconds supportable to the naked eye, and in brightness far exceeded any thing I ever beheld— It was remarkable that for two or three minutes before the Sun’s disappearance, it could be looked at without the shelter of a glass; though it was so immediately intolerable on its return.— The effect of the momentary gloom was heightened by the contrasted splendor of the day, before and after. The Cattle, and poultry discovered the symptoms of Night, and followed their usual habits on its approach— The swallows appeared surprized, and flew with that wild irregularity, which is described as betokening the approach of an Earthquake.— The atmosphere had the chilness of Night but there was no fall of dew— Upon the whole the phenomenon was principally curious on account of its uncommonness— Having never occurred at this place since the settlement of the Country; and being not to happen again for several centuries— Mr: Bussey entertained us with a cold collation, between the first re-appearance of the Sun, and the end of the Eclipse— I dined at Sheriff Allen’s, in Company with Governor Strong, and several other Gentlemen— In the afternoon I was somewhat unwell— Read Marmontel, late at Night.

17. William Smith junr: brought me an application from the Students at the University, for a copy of my last Week’s discourse to be printed; which I agreed to furnish them— I received yesterday a letter from Mrs: Adams, with the deed of my house in half-Court-Square to Andrew Dexter, executed by her— I was all this morning engaged in this business, without closing it; and in writing to the Assignees of Robert Bird, respecting the Judgment against H. Jackson— I dined with Mr Boylston at Jamaica-Plains— Mr: D. Sears took me out with him, and brought me back at Night. My father and brother were there from Quincy, and several other Gentlemen from Boston— In the Evening and Night I was very severely afflicted with the tooth-ache. I intended to have gone this day to Cambridge, but was prevented, by Mr: Sears’s Offer to take me out with him.

18. This afternoon I went up to Cambridge, and called at Dr: Waterhouse’s, to ascertain when I could remove thither— He has agreed to give me a chamber in his House and to board me for this summer.— And they will be ready to receive me the day after to-morrow— I next called at President Webber’s, to enquire whether the days had been fixed for the delivery of my public Lectures— But he was engaged with the other members of the College Government, and the subject was before them for determination— I also stop’d for about half an hour at Judge Dana’s— Return’d to Boston about 9 in the Evening.

div.p: 19. I this day resumed partially the studies which have been too long interrupted—wrote a little in continuation of the 4th: lecture, and began over again the first; a process which I find absolutely necessary— From the copiousness of my subject so far as I have heretofore gone I expect to make two Lectures out of each one that I have written; and I find much which must be rejected as well as much to be added— After spending the greater part of the day at home, I walk’d a couple of hours in the Evening with J. Gardner.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 20. Continued my studies this day— But found so much time engross’d by writing over a sufficient portion of the first Lecture, that I had none to continue that upon which I had only begun— Read Marmontel’s Memoirs— In the Evening I came and took my abode for the Summer at Dr: Waterhouse’s, in Cambridge— Mr: Shaw came with me, and took the Horse and Chair back— Here I hope to have more uninterrupted leisure for the pursuit which requires all my attention, and for more constant application to what is now my peculiar duty— Thunder-Shower this Evening.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 21. I called upon Mr: Webber, the President of the College, Mr: Webber, to enquire whether the Government had fixed upon the time for the delivery of my lectures— He mentioned as a present and temporary arrangement—2 O’Clock on Fridays; and the same hour on Thursday’s for the Declamations, to which I agreed— I spent the day in writing over part of my first lecture, and in continuing the first sketch of the fourth.— Walk’d in the Evening— I had an ample portion of leisure, and employed it properly— I have only to wish that my perseverance, untill the whole course shall be finished may correspond with this beginning.

22. Heard Mr: Holmes the whole day— His afternoon discourse was occasional; with reference to the late Eclipse— The Subject which he took from it was the danger and Sin of Idolatry— He barely touched upon Superstition, which would have been a better subject for the occasion; and he did not make the most of that which he did take. Yet his sermon was ingenious, and had the advantage of putting the hearer in a train of thinking for himself.— I called this Evening at Mr: Greenleaf’s, and took a solitary Walk.— Wrote to Mrs: Adams.

23. Mr: Bartlett who keeps the town School, brought me an invitation to attend the installation of the amicable lodge of free-masons to-morrow at noon, and afterwards to dine with the Society— The day was very warm, and I pass’d it in my chamber untill the Evening— Walk alone— And bathed in the river.— My freedom from interruption hitherto enables me to write more assiduously than I could in Boston.— Finished reading Marmontel’s Memoirs.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 24. The excessive heat of the day prevented my attendance at the installation of the Masonic lodge, and at the dinner to which they had invited me— I spent the day in my chamber writing with all possible assiduity. I finished writing over for the second time my first lecture— It is now as I shall deliver it, but very unsatisfactory to myself. Two of the Scholars brought me their declamations for next Thursday to be approved— The first was Dryden’s Alexander’s Feast. In the Evening I bathed in the river, and afterwards called on President Webber to enquire, whether the arrangements for declamation, and the time for my lectures was fixed; which I found they were; and he had given notice of them to the Students this morning.

25. Third day of extreme heat— I pass’d it again in my chamber; with very close application— So much in writing that I had scarcely any time left for reading— In the Evening I bathed again in the river— Cool at Night. Serenade from the Handel Sodality.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 26. I called upon President Webber, to ask his consent that the Sophomore Class might be permitted to attend my lectures from the beginning— I was to give my first lecture to-morrow— He objected the letter of the Rules and Regulations—the two Senior Classes— I replied the Spirit of the Regulations— The Sophomores will attend of course after Commencement— To exclude them now, would be to force upon them three quarters of the Course, and deny them the first part of it, where the whole foundation is to be laid— He still objected the letter of the Law, and. I determined to postpone my first Lecture, and write to the Corporation, for another modification of the Rules and Regulations; which I did— I met Dr: Dexter, and a young Dr: Gorham at the President’s. Heard Dr: Waterhouse deliver a short lecture on Natural History.— At 2 in the afternoon I presided for the first time at the declamations— Ten declaimed— I made a few remarks upon their speaking, and recommended to them attention to Memory—Emphasis—and Pause— Continued writing for my subsequent lectures, which engrosses all my time. Walk alone in the Evening.

27. Attended at the library, and took out some books. Called at the President’s with my letter for the Corporation— He was not at home, and I left the letter— Writing assiduously the whole day. Finished the first sketch of my fourth lecture— Walk in the Evening, and met Mr: Davenport who was coming to see me, and who had a proposal for purchasing some land belonging to the West-Boston Bridge Company.

28. Heard a lecture from Dr: Waterhouse on natural History this morning at 9. About 12. I went with him into Boston— Met Mr: Lowell in the Street, who told me he was prepared to Execute the instrument for the conveyance of his houses; but on enquiry I found Mr: A. Dexter was out of town; not expected to return for a week. Mr: Lowell also offered to give me a seat with him to go to Mr: Quincy’s; but I was desirous to see some other persons upon business; and Mr: Lowell could not wait— I could however find neither Judge Davis nor Mr: Shaw, who were the persons I wanted to see. Dined at Whitcomb’s; and in the afternoon went out in the Stage to Quincy.

29. Heard Mr: Bradford of Roxbury— He is a lively but not altogether a natural Speaker and Reader. His morning Sermon was a contrasted character of Herod and of John the Baptist.— He dined at my father’s— Mr: and Mrs: Foster were also there— They came out this morning from Boston, with one of their children who was taken so ill here that they could not come out go home at Night— I went up to my own house for some books and clothing. Wrote a letter to my wife which I left at Mr: Cranch’s, for the Post-Office.

30. Mr: Foster’s child was so ill that they were obliged to take a carriage to bring it into Boston; and I brought in his horse and Chaise. On reaching Boston I called on Mr: Shaw, who delivered me several Letters— I saw Judge Davis and had some conversation with him respecting the application I have made to the Corporation of the College— Met Mr: Boylston, and wrote a letter on his business to Mr: Caldwell— While I was writing it Mr: Shaw came in to the Suffolk Insurance Office, where I was and gave me a letter from my wife— I instantly opened it and found it a message of Misfortune— Her child—(a Son) was born dead— Her own danger had been very great— But she was so much recovered as to be able to write, herself— I finished my letter for Mr: Boylston, without discovering my own emotion— But he asked me what my account from Washington was— I told him—and left him— It was one O’Clock—and rained; but the desire of being alone determined me to walk to Cambridge immediately; which I did— They
They had dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— I retired to my chamber, after dining, myself, and there yielded to the weakness, which I had so long struggled to conceal and restrain.— I endeavoured to reason myself into resignation to the will of Heaven, and I felt duly grateful for the inestimable blessings it has given me in my other Children, and for the favour bestowed in preserving my wife through her imminent danger— Her Letter affected me deeply by its tenderness—its resignation—and its fortitude— As soon as I was able to hold a pen, I wrote to her, and to vary the scene and circumstances around her which must be painful after this Event, have invited her to come here as soon as she gets well enough to travel; without waiting my return to her in the winter at Washington— I have heretofore felt and express’d too bitterly the pangs of such disappointments— The mercy of Heaven has compensated me for all those sufferings by my two boys, who promise all that a parent’s Heart can wish from children of their age— I had given up my Heart to Hope, and Joy in the Hope of a third— It is gone— Let the rigour of the stroke help to purify my soul by affliction, and may my never ceasing gratitude flow for the blessings which remain to me by the bounty of Providence—
Day— I cannot detail it— But must refer to the close of the next Month if I see it.
